questions.question: How did the financial impact of AMT's acquisition of CoreSite in 2023, which included 24 data center facilities, evolve into changes in the structure and reporting of the Data Centers segment in 2024?
questions.answer: In 2023, AMT completed the acquisition of CoreSite for $10.4 billion, which included 24 data center facilities across eight U.S. markets, integrating them into the Data Centers segment. By 2024, AMT had restructured its reportable segments, separating U.S. & Canada property from the broader property segments and maintaining the Data Centers segment as a distinct reporting unit. This evolution reflects a strategic emphasis on the data center business post-acquisition, allowing for more transparent performance tracking of the integrated CoreSite assets.

Hop 2: CoreSite → Data Center Facilities: CoreSite's primary asset was its portfolio of 24 U.S. data center facilities.

## Table of Contents

## ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

The discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations that follow are based upon our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with GAAP. The preparation of our financial statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, revenues and ex penses, and the related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of our financial statements. Actual results may differ from these estimates and such differences could be material to the financial statements. This discussion should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements included in this Annual Report and the accompanying notes, and the information set forth under the caption 'Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates' below.

During the year ended December 31, 2024, we completed the sale of ATC TIPL. The divestiture qualified for presentation as discontinued operations. See Note 22 for further discussion. Prior to the divestiture and classification as discontinued operations, ATC TIPL's operating results were included within the Asia-Pacific property segment. Historical financial information included in Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations has been adjusted to reflect the operating results of ATC TIPL as discontinued operations for all periods presented.

During the year ended December 31, 2024, we also completed the sales of ATC Australia and ATC New Zealand. The divestitures did not qualify for presentation as discontinued operations.

During the fourth quarter of 2024, following recent divestitures, including the ATC TIPL Transaction, and changes to our organizational structure, we reviewed and changed our reportable segments. Our APAC property segment and our Africa property segment were combined into the Africa & APAC property segment. As a result, we now report our results in six  segments: U.S. & Canada property (which includes all assets in the United States and Canada, other than our data center facilities and related assets), Africa & APAC property, Europe property, Latin America property, Data Centers and Services. In evaluating financial performance in each business segment, management uses, among other factors, segment gross margin and segment operating profit (see note 20 to our consolidated financial statements included in this Annual Report). Historical financial information included in Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations has been adjusted to reflect the change in reportable segments.

## Executive Overview

We are one of the largest global REITs and a leading independent owner, operator and developer of multitenant communications real estate. Our primary business is the leasing of space on communications sites to wireless service providers, radio and television broadcast companies, wireless data providers, government agencies and municipalities and tenants in a number of other industries. In addition to the communications sites in our portfolio, we manage rooftop and tower sites for property owners under various contractual arrangements. We also hold other telecommunications infrastructure and property interests that we lease primarily to communications service providers and third-party tower operators, and, as discussed further below, we hold a portfolio of highly interconnected data center facilities and related assets in the United States. Our customers include our tenants, licensees and other payers. We refer to the business encompassing the above as our property operations, which accounted for 98% of our total revenues for the year ended December 31, 2024 and includes our U.S. & Canada property, Africa & APAC property, Europe property and Latin America property segments and Data Centers segment.

We also offer tower-related services in the United States, including site application, zoning and permitting, structural and mount analyses, and construction management, which primarily support our site leasing business, including the addition of new tenants and equipment on our sites.

questions.answer: In 2023, AMT partnered with DIT as part of a strategic review of its India business, which led to the ATC TIPL Transaction. The impairment charges from 2023 directly influenced the financial outcome of the 2024 sale, as the reduced asset valuations contributed to the significant loss on disposal.

## 22.    DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS

In 2023, the Company undertook a strategic review of its India operations, where the Company evaluated the appropriate level of exposure to the India market within its global portfolio of communications assets, and assessed opportunities to repurpose capital to drive long-term shareholder value and sustained growth. The strategic review concluded in January 2024 with the signed agreement for the ATC TIPL Transaction (as defined below).

On January 4, 2024, the Company, through ATC TIPL, entered into an agreement with Data Infrastructure Trust ('DIT'), an infrastructure investment trust sponsored by an affiliate of Brookfield Asset Management, pursuant to which DIT agreed to acquire a 100% ownership interest in ATC TIPL (the 'ATC TIPL Transaction'). Per the terms of the agreement, total aggregate consideration represented up to approximately 210 billion Indian Rupees ('INR') (approximately $2.5 billion), including the value of the VIL OCDs and the VIL Shares (each as defined and further discussed in note 11), payments on certain existing customer receivables, the repayment of existing intercompany debt and the repayment, or assumption, of the Company's existing term loan in India, by DIT.

During the year ended December 31, 2024, ATC TIPL distributed approximately 29.6 billion INR (approximately $354.1 million) to the Company, which included the value of the VIL Shares and the VIL OCDs and the satisfaction of the economic benefit associated with the rights to payments on certain existing customer receivables. The distributions were deducted from the total aggregate consideration received by the Company at closing.

The ATC TIPL Transaction received all government and regulatory approvals during the three months ended September 30, 2024, and on September 12, 2024, the Company completed the sale of ATC TIPL and received total consideration of 182 billion INR (approximately $2.2 billion). The Company used the proceeds from the ATC TIPL Transaction to repay existing indebtedness under the 2021 Multicurrency Credit Facility.

The Company recorded a loss on the sale of ATC TIPL of $1.2 billion, which primarily included the reclassification of the Company's cumulative translation adjustment in India upon exiting the market of $1.1 billion. The loss on sale of ATC TIPL is included in Loss from discontinued operations, net of taxes in the consolidated statements of operations for year ended December 31, 2024.

questions.question: How did the treatment and valuation of SPG's noncontrolling redeemable interests evolve between 2022 and 2024, particularly in relation to the redemption options available to limited partners and the impact on equity classification?
questions.answer: In 2022, SPG disclosed noncontrolling redeemable interests in properties and classified them as temporary equity due to the potential for redemption in cash, with adjustments made to the carrying amount based on redemption value. By 2024, the redemption option remained available to limited partners in the Operating Partnership, who could exchange units for cash or shares of common stock on a one-for-one basis, with the cash amount based on the trading price of SPG common stock. SPG maintained the ability to determine whether redemptions were settled in cash or stock, but if cash was selected and insufficient funds were available, the exchange would default to stock. This evolution shows a continued emphasis on flexibility in redemption settlement while maintaining the temporary equity classification due to the contingent cash redemption risk.

Hop 2: Noncontrolling Redeemable Interests → Redemption Option: Redemption features could require cash settlement, influencing equity classification
Hop 3: Redemption Option ← SPG(2024): SPG maintained the right to redeem units for cash or stock, with the cash value tied to stock price, and reserved 56,002,333 shares for potential stock issuance

questions.answer: In 2022, AMT disclosed that amounts due under the 2015 Securitization and Trust Securitizations were paid from cash flows deposited into reserve accounts, which were controlled by trustees and distributed solely according to the terms of the agreements. By 2024, the reserve account balances had increased significantly — from undisclosed 2022 levels to $53.9 million for the Trust Securitizations and $6.9 million for the 2015 Securitization — indicating tighter adherence to securitization covenants and a more structured cash flow management approach. This was consistent with AMT being in compliance with all covenants as of December 31, 2024, suggesting that the company had refined its securitization strategy to better manage liquidity and reduce default risk, particularly in light of the increased reserve requirements and trustee oversight.

## 2. Basis of Presentation and Consolidation

The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of all controlled subsidiaries, and all significant intercompany amounts have been eliminated.

We consolidate properties that are wholly-owned or properties where we own less than 100% but we control. Control  of  a  property  is  demonstrated  by,  among  other  factors,  our  ability  to  refinance  debt  and  sell  the  property without the consent of any other partner or owner and the inability of any other partner or owner to replace us.

We also consolidate a variable interest entity, or VIE, when we are determined to be the primary beneficiary. Determination of the primary beneficiary of a VIE is based on whether an entity has (1) the power to direct activities that most significantly impact the economic performance of the VIE and (2) the obligation to absorb losses or the right to  receive  benefits  of  the  VIE  that  could  potentially  be  significant  to  the  VIE.  Our  determination  of  the  primary beneficiary of a VIE considers all relationships between us and the VIE, including management agreements and other contractual arrangements. There have been no changes during 2021 in previous conclusions about whether an entity qualifies  as  a  VIE  or  whether  we  are  the  primary  beneficiary  of  any  previously  identified  VIE.  During  the  periods presented, we did not provide financial or other support to any identified VIE that we were not contractually obligated to provide.

Investments in partnerships and joint ventures represent our noncontrolling ownership interests. We account for these unconsolidated entities using the equity method of accounting. We initially record these investments at cost and we subsequently adjust for net equity in income or loss, which we allocate in accordance with the provisions of the  applicable  partnership  or  joint  venture  agreement,  cash  contributions  and  distributions,  and  foreign  currency fluctuations,  if  applicable.  The  allocation  provisions  in  the  partnership  or  joint  venture  agreements  are  not  always consistent with the legal ownership interests held by each general or limited partner or joint venture investee primarily due  to  partner  preferences.  We  separately  report  investments  in  partnerships  and  joint  ventures  for  which accumulated distributions have exceeded investments in and our share of net income of the partnerships and joint ventures within cash distributions and losses in partnerships and joint ventures, at equity in the consolidated balance sheets. The net equity of certain partnerships and joint ventures is less than zero because of financing or operating distributions that are usually greater than net income, as net income includes non-cash charges for depreciation and amortization.

As of December 31, 2021, we consolidated 131 wholly-owned properties and 17 additional properties that are less than wholly-owned, but which we control or for which we are the primary beneficiary. We apply the equity method of  accounting  to  the  other  84  properties  (the  joint  venture  properties)  and  our  investments  in  Klépierre  (a  publicly traded, Paris-based real estate company) and The Taubman Realty Group, LLC, or TRG, as well as our investments in  certain  entities  involved  in  retail  operations,  such  as  J.C.  Penney  and  SPARC  Group;  intellectual  property  and licensing  ventures,  such  as  Authentic  Brands  Group,  LLC,  or  ABG,  and  Eddie  Bauer  Ipco;  and  an  e-commerce venture  Rue  Gilt  Groupe,  or  RGG,  (collectively,  our  other  platform  investments).    We  manage  the  day-to-day operations of 53 of the 84 joint venture properties, but have determined that our partner or partners have substantive participating rights with respect to the assets and operations of these joint venture properties. Our investments in joint ventures in Japan, South Korea, Mexico, Malaysia, Canada, Spain, Thailand, and the United Kingdom comprise 23 of the  remaining  31  properties.  These  international  properties  and  TRG  are  managed  by  joint  ventures  in  which  we share control.

Preferred distributions of the Operating Partnership are accrued at declaration and represent distributions on outstanding preferred units of partnership interests, or preferred units, and are included in net income attributable to noncontrolling interests.  We allocate net operating results of the Operating Partnership after preferred distributions to limited partners and to us based on the partners' respective weighted average ownership interests in the Operating Partnership.  Net  operating  results  of  the  Operating  Partnership  attributable  to  limited  partners  are  reflected  in  net income attributable to noncontrolling interests.

questions.question: How did the conversion and subsequent sale of the VIL OCDs in 2024 impact AMT's financial position compared to their initial recognition and fair value assessment in 2023?
questions.answer: In 2023, AMT initially recognized the VIL OCDs with a face value of INR 16.0 billion (approximately $193.2 million) and a fair value of $116.5 million. By 2024, AMT converted INR 14.4 billion (approximately $172.7 million) of the VIL OCDs into VIL equity shares and sold both the shares and the remaining VIL OCDs, generating total net proceeds of approximately $238 million and recognizing a gain of $46.4 million. This transformation from a debt instrument with uncertain collectability to a realized gain in 2024 significantly improved AMT's financial outcome related to this exposure, while also eliminating future risk associated with VIL.

Hop 2: VIL OCDs → VIL: The VIL OCDs were issued by VIL and convertible into equity, representing a financial dependency of AMT on VIL’s creditworthiness and market performance.
Hop 3: VIL ← AMT(2024): In 2024, AMT converted and sold the VIL OCDs and related equity, realizing a total gain of $46.4 million and eliminating exposure to VIL.

Most	of	our	tenant	leases	for	our	communications	sites	have	provisions	that	periodically	increase	or 'escalate'	the	rent	due	under	the	lease,	typically	based	on	(a)	an	annual	fixed	escalation	(averaging	approximately	3%	in	the United	States)	or	(b)	an	inflationary	index	in	most	of	our	international	markets,	or	a	combination	of	both. In	February	2023,	and	as	amended	in	August	2023,	VIL	issued	the	VIL	OCDs,	which	are	(a)	to	be	repaid	by	VIL	with	interest,	or (b)	convertible	into	equity	of	VIL. The	VIL	OCDs	were	issued	for	an	aggregate	face	value	of 16.0	billion	Indian	Rupees	('INR')	(approximately	$193.2	million	on	the	date	of	issuance)	and	will	mature	on	August	27,	2024. VIL Optionally Convertible Debentures -In February 2023, and as amended in August 2023, one of the Company's customers in India, Vodafone Idea Limited ('VIL'), issued optionally convertible debentures (the 'VIL OCDs') to the Company's subsidiary, ATC TIPL, in exchange for VIL's payment of certain amounts towards accounts receivables. The VIL OCDs were (a) to be repaid by VIL with interest or (b) convertible into equity of VIL. The VIL OCDs were issued for an aggregate face value of 16.0 billion INR (approximately $193.2 million on the date of issuance). The VIL OCDs were to mature in tranches with 8.0 billion INR (approximately $96.6 million on the date of issuance) maturing on August 27, 2023 and 8.0 billion INR (approximately $96.6 million on the date of issuance) maturing on August 27, 2024. In August 2023, the Company amended the agreements governing the VIL OCDs to, among other items, extend the maturity of the first tranche of the VIL OCDs to August 27, 2024. The fair value of the VIL OCDs at issuance was approximately $116.5 million. The VIL OCDs accrued interest at a rate of 11.2% annually. Interest was payable to ATC TIPL semi-annually, with the first payment received in September 2023.

On March 23, 2024, the Company converted an aggregate face value of 14.4 billion INR (approximately $172.7 million) of VIL OCDs into 1,440 million shares of equity of VIL (the 'VIL Shares').

On April 29, 2024, the Company completed the sale of 1,440 million VIL Shares at a price of 12.78 INR per share. The net proceeds for this transaction were approximately 18.0 billion INR (approximately $216.0 million at the date of settlement) after deducting commissions and fees.

On June 5, 2024, the Company completed the sale of the remaining aggregate face value of 1.6 billion INR (approximately $19.2 million) of the VIL OCDs. The net proceeds for this transaction, ex cluding accrued interest, were approx imately 1.8 billion INR (approx imately $22.0 million at the date of settlement) after deducting fees.

During the year ended December 31, 2024, the Company recognized a gain of $46.4 million on the sales of the VIL Shares and the VIL OCDs. The gains on the sales of the VIL Shares and the VIL OCDs are recorded in Loss from discontinued operations, net of taxes in the consolidated statements of operations in the current period. As of December 31, 2024, none of the VIL Shares or the VIL OCDs remained outstanding.

questions.question: How did AMT's strategic decision to divest ATC TIPL to DIT in 2023 reflect a shift in their India market exposure strategy compared to 2022, and what financial impairments preceded this decision?
questions.answer: In 2022, AMT recorded a $508.6 million impairment charge for fixed and intangible assets in India due to uncertainties around collections, particularly from VIL, which had communicated it would make partial payments. By 2023, AMT initiated a strategic review of its India business, culminating in a signed agreement with DIT for the sale of ATC TIPL, representing a full exit from its Indian tower operations. This decision was preceded by a $322.0 million goodwill impairment charge in Q3 2023, reflecting the carrying value of the India reporting unit exceeding its fair value. The divestiture, valued at up to approximately 210 billion INR ($2.5 billion), marked a strategic pivot to reduce exposure to the volatile Indian telecom market and repurpose capital for global growth.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AMT(2022) → ATC TIPL: AMT had fully redeemed all noncontrolling interests in ATC TIPL by 2021, resulting in 100% ownership, but faced significant financial strain in India due to VIL's partial payments, leading to a $508.6 million impairment in 2022.
Hop 2: ATC TIPL → DIT: In 2023, AMT initiated a strategic review of its India business and entered into an agreement for DIT to acquire ATC TIPL, marking a major strategic shift.

Hop 3: DIT ← AMT(2023): The agreement with DIT, valued at up to $2.5 billion, was finalized in early 2024, reflecting AMT’s decision to exit the Indian market, following a $322.0 million goodwill impairment linked to the deteriorating outlook for the India reporting unit.

- Impairment	of	Assets-Goodwill: We	review	goodwill	for	impairment	at	least	annually	(as	of	December	31)	or	whenever events	or	circumstances	indicate	the	carrying	amount	of	an	asset	may	not	be	recoverable.	Goodwill	is	recorded	in	the applicable	segment	and	assessed	for	impairment	at	the	reporting	unit	level.	We	employ	a	discounted	cash	flow	analysis when	testing	goodwill.	The	key	assumptions	utilized	in	the	discounted	cash	flow	analysis	include	current	operating performance,	terminal	revenue	growth	rate,	management's	expectations	of	future	operating	results	and	cash	requirements, the	current	weighted	average	cost	of	capital	and	an	expected	tax	rate.	We	compare	the	fair	value	of	the	reporting	unit, as	calculated	under	an	income	approach	using	future	discounted	cash	flows,	to	the	carrying	amount	of	the	applicable reporting	unit.	If	the	carrying	amount	exceeds	the	fair	value,	an	impairment	loss	would	be	recognized	for	the	amount	of the	excess.	The	loss	recognized	is	limited	to	the	total	amount	of	goodwill	allocated	to	that	reporting	unit.

We	performed	a	quantitative	goodwill	impairment	test	for	the	quarter	ended	September	30,	2023 using,	among	other	things,	the	information	obtained	from	third	parties	to	compare	the	fair	value	of	the	India	reporting unit	to	its	carrying	amount,	including	goodwill.	The	result	of	our	goodwill	impairment	test	indicated	that	the	carrying amount	of	our	India	reporting	unit	exceeded	our	estimated	fair	value.	As	a	result,	we	recorded	a	goodwill	impairment charge	of	$322.0	million.

The	results	of	the	annual	goodwill impairment	test	indicated	that	the	carrying	amount	of	our	Spain	reporting	unit	exceeded	its	estimated	fair	value,	as calculated	under	an	income	approach	using	future	discounted	cash	flows. questions.question: How did the change in AMT's excess cash distribution from GTP Acquisition Partners between 2022 and 2023 relate to the Cash Trap DSCR threshold and the evolution of their securitization structures?
questions.answer: In 2022, AMT's excess cash distribution from GTP Acquisition Partners was subject to the Cash Trap DSCR threshold of 1.30x, which, if breached, would restrict distributions and deposit excess cash into a reserve account. By 2023, GTP Acquisition Partners had a DSCR of 17.42x, well above the 1.30x threshold, enabling $322.1 million in excess cash to be distributed to AMT. This improvement in DSCR, combined with the completion of the 2023 Securitization, which refinanced $1.3 billion in Series 2013-2A Notes, reflects a strengthening in AMT's securitization structure and cash flow management, allowing for greater liquidity to be passed through to the parent company.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AMT(2022) → Cash Trap DSCR: AMT was subject to the Cash Trap DSCR (1.30x) in 2022, which governed the release of excess cash from GTP Acquisition Partners.
Hop 2: Cash Trap DSCR → GTP Acquisition Partners: The DSCR test applied quarterly to GTP Acquisition Partners determined whether excess cash could be distributed to AMT.

Hop 3: GTP Acquisition Partners ← AMT(2023): In 2023, GTP Acquisition Partners had a DSCR of 17.42x and distributed $322.1 million in excess cash to AMT, following the 2023 securitization refinancing.

In order to distribute any excess cash flow to the Company, the AMT Asset Subs and GTP Acquisition Partners must each maintain a specified debt service coverage ratio (the 'DSCR'), which is generally calculated as the ratio of the net cash flow (as defined in the applicable agreement) to the amount of interest, servicing fees and trustee fees required to be paid over the succeeding 12 months on the principal amount of the Loan or the 2015 Notes, as applicable, that will be outstanding on the payment date following such date of determination. Penney to a more direct but reduced ownership position in the restructured entity by 2024.

## 2. Basis of Presentation and Consolidation

The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of all controlled subsidiaries, and all significant intercompany amounts have been eliminated.

We consolidate properties that are wholly-owned or properties where we own less than 100% but we control. Control  of  a  property  is  demonstrated  by,  among  other  factors,  our  ability  to  refinance  debt  and  sell  the  property without the consent of any other partner or owner and the inability of any other partner or owner to replace us.

We also consolidate a variable interest entity, or VIE, when we are determined to be the primary beneficiary. Determination of the primary beneficiary of a VIE is based on whether an entity has (1) the power to direct activities that most significantly impact the economic performance of the VIE and (2) the obligation to absorb losses or the right to  receive  benefits  of  the  VIE  that  could  potentially  be  significant  to  the  VIE.  Our  determination  of  the  primary beneficiary of a VIE considers all relationships between us and the VIE, including management agreements and other contractual arrangements. There have been no changes during 2021 in previous conclusions about whether an entity qualifies  as  a  VIE  or  whether  we  are  the  primary  beneficiary  of  any  previously  identified  VIE.  During  the  periods presented, we did not provide financial or other support to any identified VIE that we were not contractually obligated to provide.

Investments in partnerships and joint ventures represent our noncontrolling ownership interests. We account for these unconsolidated entities using the equity method of accounting. We initially record these investments at cost and we subsequently adjust for net equity in income or loss, which we allocate in accordance with the provisions of the  applicable  partnership  or  joint  venture  agreement,  cash  contributions  and  distributions,  and  foreign  currency fluctuations,  if  applicable.  The  allocation  provisions  in  the  partnership  or  joint  venture  agreements  are  not  always consistent with the legal ownership interests held by each general or limited partner or joint venture investee primarily due  to  partner  preferences.  We  separately  report  investments  in  partnerships  and  joint  ventures  for  which accumulated distributions have exceeded investments in and our share of net income of the partnerships and joint ventures within cash distributions and losses in partnerships and joint ventures, at equity in the consolidated balance sheets. The net equity of certain partnerships and joint ventures is less than zero because of financing or operating distributions that are usually greater than net income, as net income includes non-cash charges for depreciation and amortization.

As of December 31, 2021, we consolidated 131 wholly-owned properties and 17 additional properties that are less than wholly-owned, but which we control or for which we are the primary beneficiary. We apply the equity method of  accounting  to  the  other  84  properties  (the  joint  venture  properties)  and  our  investments  in  Klépierre  (a  publicly traded, Paris-based real estate company) and The Taubman Realty Group, LLC, or TRG, as well as our investments in  certain  entities  involved  in  retail  operations,  such  as  J.C.  Penney  and  SPARC  Group;  intellectual  property  and licensing  ventures,  such  as  Authentic  Brands  Group,  LLC,  or  ABG,  and  Eddie  Bauer  Ipco;  and  an  e-commerce venture  Rue  Gilt  Groupe,  or  RGG,  (collectively,  our  other  platform  investments).    We  manage  the  day-to-day operations of 53 of the 84 joint venture properties, but have determined that our partner or partners have substantive participating rights with respect to the assets and operations of these joint venture properties. Our investments in joint ventures in Japan, South Korea, Mexico, Malaysia, Canada, Spain, Thailand, and the United Kingdom comprise 23 of the  remaining  31  properties.  These  international  properties  and  TRG  are  managed  by  joint  ventures  in  which  we share control.

Preferred distributions of the Operating Partnership are accrued at declaration and represent distributions on outstanding preferred units of partnership interests, or preferred units, and are included in net income attributable to noncontrolling interests.  We allocate net operating results of the Operating Partnership after preferred distributions to limited partners and to us based on the partners' respective weighted average ownership interests in the Operating Partnership.  Net  operating  results  of  the  Operating  Partnership  attributable  to  limited  partners  are  reflected  in  net income attributable to noncontrolling interests.

## 2. Basis of Presentation and Consolidation

The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of all controlled subsidiaries, and all significant intercompany amounts have been eliminated.

We consolidate properties that are wholly-owned or properties where we own less than 100% but we control. Control  of  a  property  is  demonstrated  by,  among  other  factors,  our  ability  to  refinance  debt  and  sell  the  property without the consent of any other partner or owner and the inability of any other partner or owner to replace us.

We also consolidate a variable interest entity, or VIE, when we are determined to be the primary beneficiary. Determination of the primary beneficiary of a VIE is based on whether an entity has (1) the power to direct activities that most significantly impact the economic performance of the VIE and (2) the obligation to absorb losses or the right to  receive  benefits  of  the  VIE  that  could  potentially  be  significant  to  the  VIE.  Our  determination  of  the  primary beneficiary of a VIE considers all relationships between us and the VIE, including management agreements and other contractual arrangements. There have been no changes during 2021 in previous conclusions about whether an entity qualifies  as  a  VIE  or  whether  we  are  the  primary  beneficiary  of  any  previously  identified  VIE.  During  the  periods presented, we did not provide financial or other support to any identified VIE that we were not contractually obligated to provide.

Investments in partnerships and joint ventures represent our noncontrolling ownership interests. We account for these unconsolidated entities using the equity method of accounting. We initially record these investments at cost and we subsequently adjust for net equity in income or loss, which we allocate in accordance with the provisions of the  applicable  partnership  or  joint  venture  agreement,  cash  contributions  and  distributions,  and  foreign  currency fluctuations,  if  applicable.  The  allocation  provisions  in  the  partnership  or  joint  venture  agreements  are  not  always consistent with the legal ownership interests held by each general or limited partner or joint venture investee primarily due  to  partner  preferences.  We  separately  report  investments  in  partnerships  and  joint  ventures  for  which accumulated distributions have exceeded investments in and our share of net income of the partnerships and joint ventures within cash distributions and losses in partnerships and joint ventures, at equity in the consolidated balance sheets. The net equity of certain partnerships and joint ventures is less than zero because of financing or operating distributions that are usually greater than net income, as net income includes non-cash charges for depreciation and amortization.

As of December 31, 2021, we consolidated 131 wholly-owned properties and 17 additional properties that are less than wholly-owned, but which we control or for which we are the primary beneficiary. We apply the equity method of  accounting  to  the  other  84  properties  (the  joint  venture  properties)  and  our  investments  in  Klépierre  (a  publicly traded, Paris-based real estate company) and The Taubman Realty Group, LLC, or TRG, as well as our investments in  certain  entities  involved  in  retail  operations,  such  as  J.C.  Penney  and  SPARC  Group;  intellectual  property  and licensing  ventures,  such  as  Authentic  Brands  Group,  LLC,  or  ABG,  and  Eddie  Bauer  Ipco;  and  an  e-commerce venture  Rue  Gilt  Groupe,  or  RGG,  (collectively,  our  other  platform  investments).    We  manage  the  day-to-day operations of 53 of the 84 joint venture properties, but have determined that our partner or partners have substantive participating rights with respect to the assets and operations of these joint venture properties. Our investments in joint ventures in Japan, South Korea, Mexico, Malaysia, Canada, Spain, Thailand, and the United Kingdom comprise 23 of the  remaining  31  properties.  These  international  properties  and  TRG  are  managed  by  joint  ventures  in  which  we share control.

Preferred distributions of the Operating Partnership are accrued at declaration and represent distributions on outstanding preferred units of partnership interests, or preferred units, and are included in net income attributable to noncontrolling interests.  We allocate net operating results of the Operating Partnership after preferred distributions to limited partners and to us based on the partners' respective weighted average ownership interests in the Operating Partnership.  Net  operating  results  of  the  Operating  Partnership  attributable  to  limited  partners  are  reflected  in  net income attributable to noncontrolling interests.

(Tabular amounts in millions, unless otherwise disclosed)

## 22.    DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS

In 2023, the Company undertook a strategic review of its India operations, where the Company evaluated the appropriate level of exposure to the India market within its global portfolio of communications assets, and assessed opportunities to repurpose capital to drive long-term shareholder value and sustained growth. The strategic review concluded in January 2024 with the signed agreement for the ATC TIPL Transaction (as defined below).

On January 4, 2024, the Company, through ATC TIPL, entered into an agreement with Data Infrastructure Trust ('DIT'), an infrastructure investment trust sponsored by an affiliate of Brookfield Asset Management, pursuant to which DIT agreed to acquire a 100% ownership interest in ATC TIPL (the 'ATC TIPL Transaction'). Per the terms of the agreement, total aggregate consideration represented up to approximately 210 billion Indian Rupees ('INR') (approximately $2.5 billion), including the value of the VIL OCDs and the VIL Shares (each as defined and further discussed in note 11), payments on certain existing customer receivables, the repayment of existing intercompany debt and the repayment, or assumption, of the Company's existing term loan in India, by DIT.

During the year ended December 31, 2024, ATC TIPL distributed approximately 29.6 billion INR (approximately $354.1 million) to the Company, which included the value of the VIL Shares and the VIL OCDs and the satisfaction of the economic benefit associated with the rights to payments on certain existing customer receivables. The distributions were deducted from the total aggregate consideration received by the Company at closing.

The ATC TIPL Transaction received all government and regulatory approvals during the three months ended September 30, 2024, and on September 12, 2024, the Company completed the sale of ATC TIPL and received total consideration of 182 billion INR (approximately $2.2 billion). The Company used the proceeds from the ATC TIPL Transaction to repay existing indebtedness under the 2021 Multicurrency Credit Facility.

The Company recorded a loss on the sale of ATC TIPL of $1.2 billion, which primarily included the reclassification of the Company's cumulative translation adjustment in India upon exiting the market of $1.1 billion. The loss on sale of ATC TIPL is included in Loss from discontinued operations, net of taxes in the consolidated statements of operations for year ended December 31, 2024.

questions.question: How did SPG's application of ASU 2020-04 in 2022 and ASU 2021-01 in 2023 impact their transition away from LIBOR in debt instruments, and what was the resulting effect on their consolidated financial statements?
questions.answer: In 2022, SPG applied ASU 2020-04, which provided optional expedients for transitioning certain debt instruments away from LIBOR to alternative benchmark indexes, with no impact reported on their consolidated financial statements. In 2023, SPG continued to comply with ASU 2021-01, an expansion of the scope of ASU 2020-04 to include derivatives, allowing continued application of the guidance through December 31, 2024. The transition was part of a broader market shift away from LIBOR, and SPG’s use of these accounting updates facilitated smoother contract modifications and hedge accounting treatments without material financial impact. The continuation of compliance through 2023 ensured consistent financial reporting during the reference rate reform period.

Hop 2: ASU 2020-04 → ASU 2021-01: ASU 2021-01 expanded the scope of ASU 2020-04 to include derivatives and extended its applicability through 2024.
Hop 3: ASU 2021-01 ← SPG(2023): SPG continued to comply with ASU 2021-01 in 2023, applying it to contract modifications and hedging relationships affected by the transition from LIBOR.

The Company sponsored, through a wholly-owned subsidiary, a special purpose acquisition corporation, or SPAC, named Simon Property Group Acquisition Holdings, Inc.  On February 18, 2021, the SPAC announced the pricing  of  its  initial  public  offering,  which  was  consummated  on  February  23,  2021,  generating  gross  proceeds  of $345.0 million, which have been placed in a trust account and is included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheet in Investments held in trust - special purpose acquisition company. ## RESEARCH	AND	DEVELOPMENT

Research	and	development	costs	for	projects	are	expensed	as	incurred,	unless	these	costs	relate	to	contracts	with	customers	where	the Company	receives	reimbursements.	Amounts	expensed	as	incurred	for	Company-sponsored	research	and	development	projects	are	included	in Research	and	development	expenses	and	were	$1,456	million,	$1,478	million,	and	$1,333	million	for	the	years	ended	December	31,	2023, 2022,	and	2021,	respectively.	Costs	related	to	contracts	with	customers	for	customer-sponsored	research	and	development	projects	are included	 as	 a	 contract	 cost	 and	 included	 in	 Cost	 of	 products	 and	 services	 sold	 when	 revenue	 from	 such	 contracts	 is	 recognized, consistent	with	the	Company's	sales	recognition	policies.	This	revenue	was	$1,303	million,	$1,336	million,	and	$1,284	million	for	the years	ended	December	31,	2023,	2022,	and	2021,	respectively.

## CASH	AND	CASH	EQUIVALENTS

Cash	and	cash	equivalents	include	cash	on	hand	and	highly	liquid	investments	having	an	original	maturity	of	three	months	or	less.

## INVENTORIES

Inventories	are	stated	at	the	lower	of	cost	or	net	realizable	value,	with	cost	determined	on	a	first-in,	first-out	basis.	Carrying	value adjustments	for	inventory	obsolescence	is	equal	to	the	difference	between	the	cost	and	net	realizable	value.	Net	realizable	value	is	the estimated	 selling	 price	 in	 the	 ordinary	 course	 of	 business,	 less	 reasonably	 predictable	 costs	 of	 completion,	 disposal,	 and transportation.

## PROPERTY,	PLANT	AND	EQUIPMENT

Property,	 plant	 and	 equipment	 are	 recorded	 at	 cost,	 including	 any	 asset	 retirement	 obligations,	 less	 accumulated	 depreciation.	 For financial	reporting,	the	straight-line	method	of	depreciation	is	used	over	the	estimated	useful	lives	of	10	to	50	years	for	buildings and	 improvements	 and	 3	 to	 16	 years	 for	 machinery	 and	 equipment.	 Recognition	 of	 the	 fair	 value	 of	 obligations	 associated	 with	 the retirement	of	tangible	long-lived	assets	is	required	when	there	is	a	legal	obligation	to	incur	such	costs.	Upon	initial	recognition	of	a liability,	the	cost	is	capitalized	as	part	of	the	related	long-lived	asset	and	depreciated	over	the	corresponding	asset's	useful	life.

## GOODWILL	AND	INDEFINITE-LIVED	INTANGIBLE	ASSETS

Goodwill	and	indefinite-lived	intangible	assets	are	subject	to	impairment	testing	annually	as	of	the	first	day	of	the	fourth	quarter,	or if	a	triggering	event	occurs	or	changes	in	circumstances	indicate	that	the	carrying	amount	may	not	be	fully	recoverable.	This	testing compares	carrying	values	to	fair	values	and,	when	appropriate,	the	carrying	value	of	these	assets	is	reduced	to	fair	value,	not	to exceed	the	carrying	value	of	goodwill.	The	Company	completed	its	annual	goodwill	impairment	test	as	of	the	first	day	of	the	fourth quarter	and	determined	there	was	no	impairment	as	of	that	date.	The	Company	is	not	aware	of	any	additional	triggering	events.

questions.question: How did the resolution of VIL's payment shortfall in 2023 influence AMT's strategic decisions regarding the VIL OCDs in 2024, and what was the financial outcome of those decisions?
questions.answer: In 2023, VIL resumed full payments on its contractual obligations to AMT, which had previously been impacted by the VIL Shortfall. This resolution allowed AMT to reassess its strategic exposure to the Indian market, ultimately leading to the decision to convert and sell the VIL OCDs in 2024. AMT converted 14.4 billion INR (approximately $172.7 million) of VIL OCDs into 1,440 million VIL shares and sold them for net proceeds of 18.0 billion INR (approximately $216.0 million). The remaining 1.6 billion INR (approximately $19.2 million) of VIL OCDs were also sold for net proceeds of 1.8 billion INR (approximately $22.0 million). These transactions resulted in a total gain of $46.4 million recognized in 2024, reflecting the financial benefit of AMT's strategic decisions following the stabilization of VIL's payments.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AMT(2023) → VIL: VIL resumed full payments after the 2022 shortfall, prompting AMT to reassess its India exposure.
Hop 2: VIL → VIL OCDs: VIL issued OCDs in 2023, which were held by AMT's Indian subsidiary ATC TIPL and carried interest at 11.2% annually.
Hop 3: VIL OCDs ← AMT(2024): In 2024, AMT converted and sold all VIL OCDs and equity, realizing a $46.4 million gain from the transactions.

questions.question: How did the redemption activity of SPG's 7.50% Cumulative Redeemable Preferred Units in 2023 and 2024 impact Simon's preferred stock premium amortization, and what does this indicate about SPG's capital structure strategy?
questions.answer: In 2023, SPG redeemed 25,000 preferred units for $2.5 million, and in 2024, it redeemed 75,000 units for $7.5 million, reducing the carrying value of these units from $23.0 million in 2023 to $15.5 million in 2024. These redemptions directly affected Simon, as the preferred distributions paid by the Operating Partnership to Simon are equal to the dividends Simon pays on its preferred stock. Correspondingly, Simon's unamortized premium on the Series J 8 3/8% Preferred Stock decreased from $1.3 million in 2023 to $0.9 million in 2024, reflecting accelerated amortization due to the increased redemption activity. This indicates that SPG is strategically reducing its preferred equity obligations, likely to optimize its capital structure by lowering preferred dividend costs over time.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: SPG(2023) → Series J 8 3/8% Preferred Stock: SPG redeemed 25,000 preferred units for $2.5 million in 2023, with a carrying value of $23.0 million.

Hop 2: Series J 8 3/8% Preferred Stock → Simon: Simon receives preferred distributions from SPG's Operating Partnership equal to the dividends it pays on its preferred stock, which includes the Series J 8 3/8% Preferred Stock issued at a $7.5 million premium.

Hop 3: Simon ← SPG(2024): In 2024, SPG redeemed 75,000 preferred units for $7.5 million, reducing the carrying value to $15.5 million, which accelerated the amortization of Simon’s preferred stock premium from $1.3 million (2023) to $0.9 million (2024).

questions.question: How did SPG's strategic investment activity in ABG during 2023 influence its ownership stake in SPARC Group by 2024, and what were the financial implications of these changes on SPG's gains from equity interest disposals?
questions.answer: In 2023, SPG participated in multiple capital transactions with ABG, including the sale of portions of its ABG interest and additional dilution events, which led to a decrease in SPG’s ownership in SPARC Group from 33.3% to an approximate 9.6% by 2024. These transactions resulted in significant gains for SPG, including a $145.8 million non-cash pre-tax gain from SPARC Group’s equity issuance in 2023 and a $414.8 million pretax gain from the full disposal of its ABG stake in 2024. The financial implications reflect SPG’s strategic shift to monetize its investments in ABG and SPARC Group, yielding over $560 million in combined gains, while reducing its exposure to these ventures.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: SPG(2023) → ABG: SPG sold portions of its ABG interest and underwent multiple dilution events, recognizing gains totaling $216.9 million in 2023.
Hop 2: ABG → SPARC Group: ABG and SPARC Group maintained a strategic partnership, particularly around Reebok operations in the U.S., which influenced SPG’s investment decisions.
Hop 3: SPARC Group ← SPG(2024): SPG’s ownership in SPARC Group was diluted to approximately 9.6% by 2024, and it fully divested its ABG stake, recognizing a $414.8 million pretax gain in 2024.

questions.question: How did the changes in AMT's debt service coverage ratio (DSCR) thresholds in 2023 and the resulting impact on GTP Acquisition Partners' excess cash flow restrictions evolve into the 2024 securitization loan agreement terms, particularly in relation to restricted cash balances?
questions.answer: In 2023, AMT's relationship with GTP Acquisition Partners was governed by securitization loan agreements that imposed two DSCR thresholds: a Cash Trap DSCR at 1.30x and a Minimum DSCR at 1.15x. If either threshold was breached, excess cash flow was restricted and either deposited into a Cash Trap Reserve Account or used to amortize debt, limiting AMT’s access to those funds. This had the potential to affect AMT’s ability to fund capital expenditures and meet REIT distribution requirements. By 2024, the structure remained largely intact, but the restricted cash balance held in these reserve accounts decreased from $76.3 million in 2023 to $60.8 million in 2024, suggesting either improved compliance with DSCR thresholds or a reduction in excess cash flow generation. The continued reliance on these DSCR-based restrictions shows that AMT’s financial performance remained closely tied to the performance of GTP Acquisition Partners under the securitization loan agreements, with the same mechanisms in place to control cash flow distribution.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AMT(2023) → GTP Acquisition Partners: AMT depended on GTP Acquisition Partners' cash flow, which was restricted if DSCR thresholds (1.30x and 1.15x) were breached, impacting AMT’s liquidity.

Hop 2: GTP Acquisition Partners → Securitization Loan Agreements: GTP Acquisition Partners was subject to the Securitization Loan Agreements, which governed cash flow distribution based on DSCR compliance and reserve account usage.

Hop 3: Securitization Loan Agreements ← AMT(2024): In 2024, AMT remained dependent on the same securitization structure, with restricted cash balances decreasing to $60.8 million, indicating a potential improvement or shift in cash flow dynamics.

questions.question: How did the change in the number of communications sites securing the Series 2015-2 Notes between 2023 and 2024 affect AMT's equity interests structure and its overall securitized debt strategy?
questions.answer: In 2023, the Series 2015-2 Notes were secured by 3,343 communications sites, while in 2024, the number of secured sites decreased slightly to 3,338. This reduction in the number of sites likely prompted a reassessment of the collateral base supporting the notes, which are secured by mortgages, deeds of trust, and a security interest in GTP Acquisition Partners' equity interests in its subsidiaries. In response, AMT adjusted its securitized debt strategy by completing the $1.3 billion 2023 Securitization, which expanded the Trust’s secured assets to include 5,029 broadcast and wireless communications towers. This broader collateral pool under the Trust Loan Agreement indicates a shift toward a more diversified and larger asset-backed financing structure, reducing reliance on the older Series 2015-2 Notes’ collateral base and leveraging newer securitization vehicles.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AMT(2023) → Equity Interests: In 2023, GTP Acquisition Partners' equity interests in its subsidiaries were pledged as security for the Series 2015-2 Notes, which were secured by 3,343 communications sites.

Hop 2: Equity Interests → Series 2015-2 Notes: The Series 2015-2 Notes depend on the equity interests in GTP Acquisition Partners, which are secured by the communications sites and personal property of the GTP Entities.

Hop 3: Series 2015-2 Notes ← AMT(2024): In 2024, the number of communications sites securing the Series 2015-2 Notes decreased to 3,338, and AMT expanded its securitized debt strategy through the Trust Loan Agreement, which included 5,029 Trust Sites.

questions.question: How did SPG's strategic investment in J.C. Penney in 2023 influence its ownership changes in SPARC Group in 2024, particularly in light of J.C. Penney's acquisition of SPARC Group's retail operations?
questions.answer: In 2023, SPG had a strategic investment in J.C. Penney and also held a noncontrolling interest in SPARC Group, which was diluted to 33.3% in Q3 2023, resulting in a $145.8 million pre-tax gain. In 2024, J.C. Penney completed an all-equity acquisition of SPARC Group's retail operations, forming Catalyst, in which SPG now holds a 31.3% noncontrolling interest. This transaction led to a $100.5 million non-cash pre-tax gain for SPG. The 2023 investment in J.C. Penney appears to have been a precursor to the 2024 consolidation of SPARC Group's retail assets under J.C. Penney, which SPG followed through reduced direct ownership in SPARC and a new structure under Catalyst. This reflects a strategic evolution in SPG's retail portfolio positioning through the entity chain.

Hop 2: J.C. Penney → SPARC Group: In 2024, J.C. Penney acquired SPARC Group’s retail operations in an all-equity transaction, forming Catalyst.
Hop 3: SPARC Group ← SPG(2024): SPG’s ownership in SPARC Group was further reduced in 2024, and it now holds a 31.3% interest in the newly formed Catalyst entity.

questions.question: How did SPG's strategic investment in SPARC Group in 2023 influence its subsequent divestiture decisions with ABG in 2024, particularly in light of SPARC Group's earlier partnership with ABG?
questions.answer: In 2023, SPG held a 33.3% noncontrolling interest in SPARC Group, which had formed a strategic partnership with ABG to operate Reebok in the U.S. During the third quarter of 2023, SPARC Group issued equity to a third party, diluting SPG’s ownership and triggering a non-cash pre-tax gain of $145.8 million. This dilution may have signaled a strategic shift in SPG’s involvement with SPARC Group and its downstream relationships, including with ABG. In late 2023, SPG sold a portion of its ABG stake for $300.2 million, recognizing a $157.1 million gain. By Q1 2024, SPG completed the full divestiture of its remaining ABG interest for $1.2 billion, realizing a pretax gain of $414.8 million. The earlier dilution in SPARC Group appears to have initiated a broader strategic retreat from its retail platform investments, culminating in the full exit from ABG in 2024.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: SPG(2023) → SPARC Group: SPG held a 33.3% noncontrolling interest in SPARC Group in 2023 and recognized a $145.8 million non-cash gain after SPARC Group issued equity to a third party.

Hop 2: SPARC Group → ABG: SPARC Group had a strategic partnership with ABG to operate Reebok in the U.S., indicating a core business relationship influencing SPG’s broader retail platform investment strategy.

Hop 3: ABG ← SPG(2024): In 2024, SPG fully exited its ABG position for $1.2 billion, realizing a $414.8 million pretax gain, following a partial sale in late 2023 for $300.2 million with a $157.1 million gain.

questions.question: How did the changes in SPG's Series J 8 3/8% Preferred Stock carrying value and redemption terms between 2022 and 2024 reflect Simon's evolving role as issuer and partner in SPG's capital structure?
questions.answer: In 2022, SPG disclosed that the Series J 8 3/8% Cumulative Redeemable Preferred Stock was issued at a premium of $7.5 million, with an unamortized premium of $1.9 million at year-end. By 2024, the unamortized premium had decreased to $0.9 million, indicating ongoing amortization of the original premium. The redemption terms remained consistent, with Simon retaining the right to redeem shares on or after October 15, 2027, at $50.00 per share plus accumulated and unpaid dividends. Meanwhile, Simon, as both issuer of the preferred stock and partner in SPG, saw the carrying value of preferred units held by it drop from $25.5 million in 2022 to $15.5 million in 2024, reflecting redemptions of 75,000 units in 2024 and 25,000 units in 2023, totaling $10 million in redemptions over two years. This reduction indicates a strategic shift in SPG’s capital structure, with Simon actively managing its preferred equity exposure through redemptions, while maintaining its role as issuer of the preferred stock.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: SPG(2022) → Series J 8 3/8% Preferred Stock: SPG disclosed the issuance of Series J preferred stock with a $7.5 million premium and $1.9 million unamortized premium at year-end.
Hop 2: Series J 8 3/8% Preferred Stock → Simon: Simon is the issuer of the Series J preferred stock and also holds the corresponding preferred units in SPG’s Operating Partnership.

Hop 3: Simon ← SPG(2024): By 2024, Simon had redeemed $10 million in preferred units (75,000 in 2024 and 25,000 in 2023), reducing the carrying value from $25.5 million in 2022 to $15.5 million in 2024.

questions.question: How did the resolution of the VIL payment shortfall in 2023 influence AMT's strategic financial decisions regarding the VIL OCDs in 2024, particularly in light of the impairment charges recorded in 2022 and 2023?
questions.answer: In 2023, VIL resumed full payments after a period of partial payments (the 'VIL Shortfall'), which had led AMT to record reserves and impairments totaling $508.6 million in 2022 and an additional $322.0 million goodwill impairment in 2023. This resolution likely contributed to AMT’s decision to convert and sell the VIL OCDs in 2024. Specifically, in March 2024, AMT converted 14.4 billion INR ($172.7 million) of VIL OCDs into equity, and subsequently sold those shares in April 2024 for $216.0 million. It also sold the remaining 1.6 billion INR ($19.2 million) of OCDs in June 2024, realizing a total gain of $46.4 million. These actions suggest that AMT used the improved financial stability of VIL to monetize its position in the OCDs, turning a previously risky receivable into a realized gain, while also reducing exposure to a volatile Indian market that had previously required significant impairment charges.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AMT(2023) → VIL: VIL resumed full payments after partial payments in 2022 and early 2023, which had led to impairment charges totaling $508.6 million in 2022 and a $322.0 million goodwill impairment in 2023.

Hop 2: VIL → VIL OCDs: VIL issued OCDs in February 2023 (amended in August 2023) with a face value of 16.0 billion INR (~$193.2 million), which were convertible into equity or repayable with interest by August 2024.
Hop 3: VIL OCDs ← AMT(2024): AMT converted and sold the VIL OCDs in 2024, realizing $216.0 million from the equity sale and $22.0 million from the remaining OCDs, with a total gain of $46.4 million.

questions.question: How did AMT's strategic decision to divest ATC TIPL to DIT in 2024 impact the financial outcomes compared to the initial agreement terms disclosed in 2023, particularly in relation to the value of the VIL OCDs and the final proceeds received?
questions.answer: In 2023, AMT disclosed the Pending ATC TIPL Transaction with DIT, which included the value of the VIL OCDs (~$116.5 million at issuance) as part of the total aggregate consideration of up to 210 billion INR (~$2.5 billion). By 2024, the transaction was finalized with total consideration of 182 billion INR (~$2.2 billion), reflecting a reduction of ~$300 million from the upper bound of the initial estimate. During the year ended December 31, 2024, ATC TIPL distributed ~$354.1 million to AMT, which included the value of the VIL OCDs and VIL Shares, satisfying the economic benefit retained by AMT. However, AMT recorded a $1.2 billion loss on the sale, primarily due to the reclassification of cumulative translation adjustments. This indicates that while the VIL OCDs contributed to the final proceeds, the overall financial outcome was significantly impacted by the translation losses upon exiting the Indian market.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AMT(2023) → ATC TIPL: AMT disclosed its pending transaction to sell ATC TIPL to DIT for up to 210 billion INR (~$2.5 billion), including the value of the VIL OCDs (~$116.5 million at issuance).
Hop 2: ATC TIPL → DIT: DIT agreed to acquire 100% ownership of ATC TIPL, with the transaction expected to close in the second half of 2024, subject to regulatory approvals.

Hop 3: DIT ← AMT(2024): The transaction closed in September 2024, with AMT receiving 182 billion INR (~$2.2 billion), and ATC TIPL distributing ~$354.1 million to AMT, including the VIL OCDs and receivables, but resulting in a $1.2 billion loss on sale.

## 22.    DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS

In 2023, the Company undertook a strategic review of its India operations, where the Company evaluated the appropriate level of exposure to the India market within its global portfolio of communications assets, and assessed opportunities to repurpose capital to drive long-term shareholder value and sustained growth. The strategic review concluded in January 2024 with the signed agreement for the ATC TIPL Transaction (as defined below).

On January 4, 2024, the Company, through ATC TIPL, entered into an agreement with Data Infrastructure Trust ('DIT'), an infrastructure investment trust sponsored by an affiliate of Brookfield Asset Management, pursuant to which DIT agreed to acquire a 100% ownership interest in ATC TIPL (the 'ATC TIPL Transaction'). Per the terms of the agreement, total aggregate consideration represented up to approximately 210 billion Indian Rupees ('INR') (approximately $2.5 billion), including the value of the VIL OCDs and the VIL Shares (each as defined and further discussed in note 11), payments on certain existing customer receivables, the repayment of existing intercompany debt and the repayment, or assumption, of the Company's existing term loan in India, by DIT.

During the year ended December 31, 2024, ATC TIPL distributed approximately 29.6 billion INR (approximately $354.1 million) to the Company, which included the value of the VIL Shares and the VIL OCDs and the satisfaction of the economic benefit associated with the rights to payments on certain existing customer receivables. The distributions were deducted from the total aggregate consideration received by the Company at closing.

The ATC TIPL Transaction received all government and regulatory approvals during the three months ended September 30, 2024, and on September 12, 2024, the Company completed the sale of ATC TIPL and received total consideration of 182 billion INR (approximately $2.2 billion). The Company used the proceeds from the ATC TIPL Transaction to repay existing indebtedness under the 2021 Multicurrency Credit Facility.

The Company recorded a loss on the sale of ATC TIPL of $1.2 billion, which primarily included the reclassification of the Company's cumulative translation adjustment in India upon exiting the market of $1.1 billion. The loss on sale of ATC TIPL is included in Loss from discontinued operations, net of taxes in the consolidated statements of operations for year ended December 31, 2024.

questions.question: How did the changes in SPG's mortgage debt structure between 2023 and 2024 affect the company's exposure to cross-default provisions and its ability to meet financial covenants?
questions.answer: In 2023, SPG had $5.2 billion in mortgage indebtedness with cross-default provisions affecting five properties across two pools, increasing exposure to potential acceleration if any single mortgage defaulted. By 2024, SPG's financing strategy included greater reliance on unsecured debt through the $2.0 billion Commercial Paper program and Supplemental Facility, which introduced financial covenants tied to corporate credit ratings. This shift likely reduced SPG's exposure to property-level cross-default risks but increased sensitivity to credit rating changes, as seen in the Supplemental Facility's SOFR plus 72.5 basis point rate based on current ratings. The transition from secured to unsecured financing reflects a strategic move to manage covenant compliance more flexibly while reducing asset-specific risk.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: SPG(2023) → Cross Default Provisions: SPG had $5.2 billion in mortgage debt with cross-default provisions affecting five properties across two pools.
Hop 2: Cross Default Provisions → Financial Covenants: Cross-default provisions could lead to debt acceleration, similar to covenant breaches under unsecured debt agreements.

Hop 3: Financial Covenants ← SPG(2024): SPG's 2024 financing relied on unsecured debt with covenants tied to corporate credit ratings, including a Supplemental Facility interest rate of SOFR + 72.5 bps based on current ratings.

questions.question: How did the cross-default provisions in AMT's $3.0 billion Revolving Credit Agreement, established in 2022, constrain its ability to manage debt and distribute capital in 2024, particularly in light of inflationary pressures and higher interest rates?
questions.answer: In 2022, AMT entered into a $3.0 billion Revolving Credit Agreement that included cross-default provisions, which meant that a payment default or acceleration under certain other material debt agreements could trigger defaults under this facility. By 2024, these provisions constrained AMT's financial flexibility, particularly as inflationary pressures and higher interest rates increased borrowing costs and limited its ability to incur additional debt or distribute capital to shareholders. The 2024 filing specifically notes that cross-default provisions in credit agreements could lead to accelerated repayment demands, which, given the already elevated interest rate environment, made it more challenging for AMT to manage liquidity and meet REIT distribution requirements without jeopardizing its financial position.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AMT(2022) → Revolving Credit Agreement: Entered into a $3.0 billion unsecured revolving credit facility with cross-default provisions tied to other material indebtedness.
Hop 2: Revolving Credit Agreement → Cross Default Provisions: The agreement included clauses that allowed for cross-defaults if AMT defaulted on other significant debt obligations.

Hop 3: Cross Default Provisions ← AMT(2024): In 2024, these provisions limited AMT’s ability to manage debt and distribute capital due to concerns over triggering cross-defaults, especially amid inflation and rising interest rates.

In an inflationary environment, such as the current economic environment, depending on the terms of our contracts and other economic conditions, we may be unable to raise prices enough to keep up with the rate of inflation or our customers may be unwilling to pay contractual increases or demand discounts upon renewal, which would reduce our profit margins and returns. If we are unable to increase our prices to offset the effects of inflation, our business, results of operations and financial condition could be materially and adversely affected. Inflation has also contributed to foreign currency exchange rate volatility, including in several of the markets where we operate. The ongoing impact of inflation may continue to create foreign exchange rate instability in our international markets, including in markets such as Africa and Latin America, that could, in turn, depress the value of that market's currency, thereby adversely impacting our business, results of operations, financial condition or the underlying value of foreign subsidiaries.

In addition, inflation is often accompanied by higher interest rates. Although the Federal Reserve Board and other central banks began cutting interest rates in the latter part of 2024, interest rates remain above recent norms. The combination of higher interest rates and high inflation could lead to an ex tended economic downturn, which could reduce our ability to incur debt or access capital and impact our results of operations and financial condition even after these conditions improve. Additionally, higher inflation or higher costs of capital could also impact the risk premiums or market returns on our assets. Changes in costs of capital could adversely impact the underlying value of our assets, which could in turn result in impairment charges.

Restrictive covenants in the agreements related to our securitization transactions, our credit facilities and our debt securities could materially and adversely affect our business by limiting flexibility, and we may be prohibited from paying dividends on our common stock, which may jeopardize our qualification for taxation as a REIT.

The agreements related to our securitization transactions include operating covenants and other restrictions customary for loans subject to rated securitizations. Among other things, the borrowers under the agreements are prohibited from incurring other indebtedness for borrowed money or further encumbering their assets. A failure to comply with the covenants in the agreements could prevent the borrowers from taking certain actions with respect to the secured assets and could prevent the borrowers from distributing any excess cash from the operation of such assets to us. If the borrowers were to default on any of the loans, the servicer on such loan could seek to foreclose upon or otherwise convert the ownership of the secured assets, in which case we could lose such assets and the cash flow associated with such assets.

The agreements for our credit facilities also contain restrictive covenants and leverage and other financial maintenance tests that could limit our ability to take various actions, including incurring additional debt, guaranteeing indebtedness or making distributions to stockholders, including our required REIT distributions, and engaging in various types of transactions, including mergers, acquisitions and sales of assets. Additionally, our credit facilities restrict our and our subsidiaries' ability to incur liens securing our or their indebtedness. These covenants could have an adverse effect on our business by limiting our ability to take advantage of financing new tower or other communications infrastructure development, mergers and acquisitions or other opportunities. Our credit agreements also contain crossdefault and/or cross-acceleration provisions, which may be triggered if we default on certain indebtedness in excess of certain thresholds. In the event of such a default, the resulting cross-defaults or cross-accelerations could have an adverse effect on our business and financial condition. Further, reporting and information covenants in our credit agreements and indentures require that we provide financial and operating information within certain time periods. If we are unable to provide the required information on a timely basis, we would be in breach of these covenants. Business -American Tower Corporation (together with its subsidiaries, 'ATC' or the 'Company') is one of the largest global real estate investment trusts and a leading independent owner, operator and developer of multitenant communications real estate. The Company's primary business is the leasing of space on communications sites to wireless service providers, radio and television broadcast companies, wireless data providers, government agencies and municipalities and tenants in a number of other industries. The Company refers to this business as its property operations. Additionally, the Company offers tower-related services in the United States, which the Company refers to as its services operations. These services include site application, zoning and permitting ('AZP') and structural analysis, which primarily support the Company's site leasing business, including the addition of new tenants and equipment on its sites. The Company's customers include its tenants, licensees and other payers.

The Company's portfolio primarily consists of towers that it owns and towers that it operates pursuant to long-term lease arrangements, as well as distributed antenna system ('DAS') networks, which provide seamless coverage solutions in certain inbuilding and outdoor wireless environments. In addition to the communications sites in its portfolio, the Company manages rooftop and tower sites for property owners under various contractual arrangements. The Company also holds other telecommunications infrastructure, fiber and property interests that it leases primarily to communications service providers and third-party tower operators and holds a portfolio of highly interconnected data center facilities and related assets in the United States that the Company leases primarily to enterprises, network operators, cloud providers and supporting service providers.

American Tower Corporation is a holding company that conducts its operations through its directly and indirectly owned subsidiaries and joint ventures. ATC's principal domestic operating subsidiaries are American Towers LLC and SpectraSite Communications, LLC. ATC conducts its international operations primarily through its subsidiary, American Tower International, Inc., which in turn conducts operations through its various international holding and operating subsidiaries and joint ventures.

The Company operates as a real estate investment trust for U.S. federal income tax purposes ('REIT'). Accordingly, the Company generally is not required to pay U.S. federal income taxes on income generated by its REIT operations, including the income derived from leasing space on its towers and in its data centers, as it receives a dividends paid deduction for distributions to stockholders that generally offsets its REIT income and gains. However, the Company remains obligated to pay U.S. federal income taxes on earnings from its domestic taxable REIT subsidiaries ('TRSs'). In addition, the Company's international assets and operations, regardless of their classification for U.S. tax purposes, continue to be subject to taxation in the jurisdictions where those assets are held or those operations are conducted.

The use of TRSs enables the Company to continue to engage in certain businesses and jurisdictions while complying with REIT qualification requirements. The Company may, from time to time, change the election of previously designated TRSs to be included as part of the REIT. As of December 31, 2021, the Company's REIT-qualified businesses included its U.S. tower leasing business, a majority of its U.S. indoor DAS networks business, its Services and Data Centers segments, as well as most of its operations in Canada, Costa Rica, France, Germany, Mexico and Nigeria. In January 2022, a majority of the Company's operations in Ghana, Kenya, South Africa and Uganda became part of the REIT.

## Risk	Management	and	Strategy

As	part	of	our	risk	management	strategy,	we	maintain	an	insurance	policy	to	cover	cybersecurity	incidents.

CoreSite	maintains	several	certifications	related	to	cybersecurity	processes	for	nearly	all	of	its	data	center	facilities, including:	(i)	System	and	Organization	Controls	(SOC)	1	Type	2	examination;	(ii)	SOC	2	Type	2	examination;	(iii) International	Organization	for	Standardization	(ISO/IEC	27001);	(iv)	National	Institute	of	Standards	and	Technology Publication	Series	800-53	(NIST	800-53)	attestation	based	on	the	high-impact	baseline	controls	and	additional	Federal	Risk and	Authorization	Management	Program	(FedRAMP)	requirements	for	a	subset	of	control	families	applicable	to	colocation services;	(v)	Payment	Card	Industry	Data	Security	Standard	(PCI	DSS)	validation;	and	(vi)	Health	Insurance	Portability	and Accountability	Act	(HIPAA)	attestation	for	the	HIPAA	Security	Rule	and	the	Health	Information	Technology	for	Economic	and Clinical	Health	Act	(HITECH)	Breach	Notification	requirements.

Our	cybersecurity	awareness	program	provides	training	for	all	global	employees	at	onboarding	and	subsequently	three	times every	year.	In	2023,	across	our	organization,	employees	completed	over	16,000	training	classes	related	to	cybersecurity. Additionally,	in	2023,	to	elevate	cybersecurity	awareness,	we	also	conducted	live	training	as	part	of	our	Employee Development	program,	sent	monthly	phishing	tips	to	all	employees	and	provided	weekly	communications	during	October,	which	is cybersecurity	awareness	month.

Operationally,	we,	along	with	CoreSite,	each	perform	periodic	penetration	testing	to	identify	weaknesses	in	systems	and networks	so	that	they	can	be	addressed	appropriately.	At	least	once	per	year,	we	also	engage	an	outside	cybersecurity	firm	to perform	independent	testing.	Our	vulnerability	management	program	is	in	place	to	adequately	identify,	classify,	prioritize and	remediate	vulnerabilities	affecting	assets.	Our	security	operations	program	monitors	our	systems	and	networks,	and	is responsible	for	investigating,	responding	to,	and	reporting	any	potential	security	incidents	in	a	timely	manner.	Our	Incident Response	Plan	includes	steps	to	determine	materiality	of	any	such	incident	and	escalate	matters	to	the	Board	and	our employees	are	regularly	trained	on	the	plan.	We	conduct	an	incident	response	exercise	at	least	annually	to	ensure	a	timely, consistent	and	compliant	response.	In	2023,	we	performed	two	separate	exercises:	(1)	a	crisis	management	tabletop	exercise that	simulated	a	ransomware	incident	and	included	participation	from	our	management,	including	our	CEO	and	CFO,	and	(2)	an IT-focused	tabletop	which	simulated	multiple	types	of	cybersecurity	incidents,	including	(a)	compromised	credentials,	(b) brute	force	attack,	(c)	uncleaned	malware	and	(d)	ransomware.	Both	of	these	tabletop	exercises	were	facilitated	by	a	thirdparty.

Our	cybersecurity	risk	management	processes	extend	to	the	oversight	and	identification	of	threats	associated	with	our	use	of third-party	vendors	and	service	providers.	We	have	in	place	a	Third-Party	Cybersecurity	Risk	Management	program	to	assess	the cybersecurity	practices	of	third-party	vendors	and	service	providers	with	access	to	our	and	CoreSite's	systems	or information.

We	have	not	been	materially	impacted	by	any	cybersecurity	threats	or	prior	cybersecurity	incidents,	including	with	respect	to our	business	strategy,	results	of	operations	or	financial	condition.	However,	we	cannot	provide	assurance	that	we	will	not	be materially	affected	in	the	future	by	such	risks,	threats	or	any	future	material	incidents.	See	'Risk	Factors'	in	Item	1A	of this	Annual	Report	on	Form	10-K	for	more	information	on	our	cybersecurity-related	risks.

questions.question: How did AMT's reliance on GTP Acquisition Partners in 2022 constrain its ability to incur new indebtedness in 2023, particularly given the 1.30x debt service coverage ratio threshold and rising inflationary pressures?
questions.answer: In 2022, AMT relied on GTP Acquisition Partners, which was subject to restrictive covenants that prohibited it from incurring additional indebtedness unless it maintained a debt service coverage ratio (DSCR) above 1.30x. This DSCR threshold determined whether excess cash flow could be released to GTP Acquisition Partners and ultimately to AMT. By 2023, rising inflation and higher interest rates increased AMT’s cost of capital and reduced its financial flexibility, making it more challenging to maintain the required DSCR. As a result, AMT’s ability to incur new indebtedness was constrained because any breach of the 1.30x DSCR could trigger cash flow restrictions and prevent the release of excess funds from GTP Acquisition Partners, directly impacting AMT’s liquidity and capacity to take on new debt.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: AMT(2022) → GTP Acquisition Partners: AMT relied on GTP Acquisition Partners, whose equity was pledged as security, with cash flow release contingent on maintaining a DSCR above 1.30x.
Hop 2: GTP Acquisition Partners → Incurring Indebtedness: GTP Acquisition Partners was restricted from incurring new indebtedness unless it met the DSCR requirement and other financial covenants.
Hop 3: Incurring Indebtedness ← AMT(2023): In 2023, inflationary pressures and higher interest rates made it harder for AMT to meet the DSCR threshold, limiting its ability to incur new debt.
